LETTER TO THE EDITOR
The accuracy of large language models in RANZCR’s clinical radiology

Dear editor,
I read with great excitement the study conducted by 
Nakaura et al., examining the potential of large language 
models (LLMs) to serve as copilots or autonomous agents in 
radiology, and addressing medical ethics and safety concerns 
[1]. I would like to demonstrate the performance of LLMs 
in answering sample questions from the clinical radiology 
phase 2 exam of the Royal Australian and New Zealand Col-
lege of Radiologists (RANZCR).
Various LLM algorithms have started to gain ground in 
assisting radiologists, in medical education, and in research 
[2]. Among these models, the generative pre-trained trans-
former 4 (GPT-4) has shown notable performance in the 
radiology board exam [3 ]. Although GPT-3.5 and Google 
Gemini provide text-based output to text-based inputs, 
GPT-4 can give text-based output to both text and image-
based inputs. The exam comprised 7 single-answer multi -
ple-choice questions and 7 short-answer questions related to 
pathology, in addition to 11 single-answer multiple-choice 
questions focused on radiology, all of which were text-based 
questions. In addition, there were 2 single-answer pictorial 
multiple choice questions and 9 short cases requiring a sin-
gle likely diagnosis as medical image-containing questions 
(https:// www. ranzcr. com/ colle ge/ docum ent- libra ry/ clini cal- 
radio logy- phase-2- 2023- exami nation- sample- quest ions). 
GPT-4, GPT-3.5, and Google Gemini achieved accuracy 
rates in pathology multiple-choice questions (100%, 85.7%, 
85.7%), short answer questions (82.1%, 81%, 69%), and 
radiology multiple-choice questions (81.8%, 27.2%, 27.2%), 
respectively. GPT-4 outperformed the other LLM models. 
In the medical image-containing part, GPT-4 achieved 50% 
accuracy in pictorial multiple-choice questions and 44.4% in 
short cases. Although GPT-4 shows effective performance 
in written lower-order and higher-order questions, it is still 
at the beginning stages in medical image-based questions. 
Studying the effectiveness of LLM models in full-text 
board exams would be beneficial. LLM models can be the 
subject of future research for clinical decision support for 
radiologists.
